title: About Me
text:
I’m Shane Curtis—a driven student, aspiring data analyst, and passionate entrepreneur currently pursuing a degree in Business Studies with a specialisation in Data Analytics at Dublin City University. I’ve always been fascinated by the intersection of business and technology, and I’m constantly exploring ways to blend my academic knowledge with real-world impact.
Over the past few years, I’ve had the privilege of launching and growing my own vintage clothing business, focusing on authentic American collegiate apparel and vintage sportswear. From sourcing unique pieces to managing sales on Depop and attending in-person vintage markets, this venture has taught me the ins and outs of e-commerce, brand building, and customer experience. It’s been a rewarding journey that reflects both my eye for style and my commitment to creating value in niche markets.
Alongside this, I play a key role in Curtis & Dunne, my family’s independent menswear business based in a small Irish town. We’re proud of our reputation for exceptional customer service, quality brands, and genuine community engagement. My involvement spans everything from marketing and retail strategy to exploring the future of fashion retail in a digital age. This hands-on experience has given me a unique perspective on the challenges and opportunities facing traditional businesses today.
Beyond my entrepreneurial pursuits, I’m committed to lifelong learning and building a well-rounded skill set. I’ve recently immersed myself in Python programming, cloud computing, and data visualization tools such as Power BI and Tableau. These tools allow me to turn raw data into meaningful insights—helping businesses make informed decisions, identify trends, and unlock new opportunities. I’m especially interested in using analytics to solve real-world problems and drive sustainable growth.
I approach every project with a mix of curiosity, creativity, and strategic thinking. Whether I’m optimizing backend processes, refining a customer segmentation model, coding a new feature for this website, or developing marketing strategies for Curtis & Dunne, I thrive when I’m learning, building, and pushing boundaries. I’m also passionate about investing, particularly in emerging technologies and global markets, and I enjoy exploring how macroeconomic trends can shape new business landscapes.
This website is more than just a portfolio—it’s a living document of my journey so far. It captures my work, my interests, and my evolving perspective as a student, entrepreneur, and future data professional. I’m always open to new collaborations, interesting conversations, or simply exchanging ideas—so don’t hesitate to get in touch. Let’s connect, build, and grow together.

title: My Work
text: This is Curtis&Dunne, my family’s menswear clothing store based in the town of Drogheda. Since opening in 2020, Curtis&Dunne has built a community of loyal customers and fostered a strong local community spirit. In the five years I’ve worked at Curtis&Dunne, I have learned so much about the day-to-day running and management of a business. In addition, I have personally overseen the social media aspect of the business and helped manage traffic flows for the e-commerce side. Curtis&Dunne has played a huge role in my development, and I continue to learn day in and day out from this family venture.

title: My Work
text:
Vintage Varsity


Vintage Varsity is my entrepreneurial venture, which I started in late 2023. As someone who has always been interested in starting my own business, I thought it would be a fun yet educational project to pursue. I created the logo, business name, and brand identity first. Following this, I sourced multiple suppliers from Cork and Dublin to Austria, where I obtain vintage American apparel such as university hoodies and sweatshirts, as well as American pro sports jerseys (NFL, NBA, MLB, and NHL).

title: My Work
text:
StockPath


StockPath is my New Enterprise Development (NED) Project, where my team was tasked with developing a business idea and a comprehensive business plan covering everything from feasibility to marketing. Our business is centered around stock management and tracking software designed to allow businesses to perform stock takes on a regular basis while streamlining the traditional, arduous stock-taking process. StockPath gives businesses the freedom to delegate stock-related tasks and gain access to key stock insights, such as best sellers and low-stock alerts.

title: My Work
text:
Bennet Hospitality Internship


I will be taking part in the Bennet Hospitality Internship in the summer of 2025, a fantastic transatlantic work opportunity. The internship was open to four students from the Business Studies final year class, and following three rounds of rigorous interviews, I was offered one of the four positions available this summer. I am excited to immerse myself in a real-world environment that promises both professional development and personal growth, while gaining valuable insights into the global hospitality industry. This internship is a fantastic opportunity that I eagerly look forward to taking part in.

title: Shane Curtis
text:
Welcome to my personal website—I’m so glad you’re here! This is a place where business, data, creativity, and entrepreneurship come together in a really fun and dynamic way. I’m currently studying Business Studies at DCU with a focus on Data Analytics, and I love digging into data to turn it into smart, actionable strategies. But that’s not all—I’m also the founder of a vintage clothing business that celebrates unique style and creative flair.
I’ve been lucky enough to be part of my family’s retail legacy at Curtis & Dunne, too, where we mix tradition with modern twists to create memorable customer experiences. Think of this site as more than just a portfolio; it’s the story of my journey, filled with projects, ideas, and insights that I’m excited to share with you. Whether you’re here to pick up a new idea, explore a potential collaboration, or just have a chat about the latest trends in art and analytics, I’m looking forward to connecting with you. Let’s dive in and see where creativity and data can take us together!

















This is my work page, where I showcase my business career up until this point!
This is my hobbies and interests page where I discuss what makes me, me!
This is my college projects page, where I showcase all of my college projects.












  



These are a selection of podcasts from which I draw great inspiration. I’ve carefully curated this list to include dynamic speakers and thought leaders whose innovative ideas and personal success stories truly resonate with me. I regularly tune in because their insights motivate me, challenge my thinking, and remind me to stay focused on my business goals. Each episode feels like a mini mentoring session that fuels my creativity and drives my entrepreneurial spirit.

title: My College Work
text: StockPath is the idea that me and my friends came up with for our college NED project. The idea came from my background in retail, as it is a stock management software solution. StockPath is a software business, built to help small business deal with the stock management issue that they face on a daily basis. We aim to create an app that pairs with a website, which will allow business owners to access valuable stock data insights at any time. We look to reduce the impacts of stock-takes too by implementing a “segmented stock-take” approach, to reduce the time consuming element of stock-takes. Click On The Image To Read The Report!

title: My Hobbies
text:
Investing


I love investing and trading because it blends strategy with excitement—it’s like a real-life puzzle where every market move challenges my analytical skills. I enjoy researching trends, assessing risks, and watching my decisions unfold in real time. It’s not only about making money; it’s about understanding the rhythm of the economy and continuously learning from each trade. This dynamic environment keeps me on my toes and fuels my passion for both the art and science of the markets.

title: My Hobbies
text:
Hiking


Hiking is a hobby I have taken up recently and is something I have gained a great passion for. I frequently drive to various mountain ranges in Ireland with my friends on the weekend. Although Ireland doesn’t have a plentiful selection of tall mountains we enjoy climbing and taking in the scenery, however I do aspire to travel abroad and tackle some more challenging mountains one day!

title: My College Work
text:
Keogh’s Strategic Report
  

For our “Business Strategy” module, me and my team chose Keogh’s as the company we wanted to analyse and strategically review. We looked at all aspects of the crisp manufacturer, from their traditional farming roots to their supply chain efficiency. As we inspected all aspects of the business, we then gave recommendations on key strategic issues that we had highlighted along the way. We then presented our findings in presentation format for our class to review. Click On The Image To View The Report!

text:
Python/Coding


Coding has been a passion of mine for a very long time, which is why when I had the chance to choose it has my final year specialisation i jumped at the chance. Along the way I have been a part of various coding projects and completed various difficult coding tasks, such as building this website or building a machine learning, classification model, built to predict company bankruptcy. In addition to this I have taken part in various Kubicle courses which have helped further my coding, data analytics and data visualisations skills. Click On The Image To Learn More!

title: Shane Curtis
text:
When I’m not exploring the intersections of business and data, I dive into the fascinating world of code. I enjoy crafting elegant solutions, building web apps, and experimenting with new technologies. Coding is both a creative outlet and a problem-solving adventure that turns ideas into reality. Check out a couple of my favorite coding projects below.
















Project One – A web application showcasing innovative coding techniques.
Project Two – An automation tool I built to simplify everyday tasks.

title: Machine Learning Project Report
text:
The aim of this project is to build a robust and interpretable classification model that can effectively predict corporate bankruptcy using traditional financial indicators. This project follows a structured machine learning pipeline: from data exploration and pre-processing, to model selection, then training, and finally evaluation. Some key challenges addressed include high dimensionality, significant class imbalance, and the need for model transparency—especially when considering the critical implications of bankruptcy misclassification.
Careful attention was given to choosing the right models for handling imbalanced binary classification, addressing differences in feature scales, and using performance metrics beyond accuracy to better evaluate how well the models could predict outcomes.



The dataset was sourced from Kaggle; it consists of 6,819 company records with 95 financial attributes and a clear binary target variable, “Bankrupt?”, which denotes whether a company had declared bankruptcy (1) or not (0). All features were continuous and complete, eliminating the need for missing value imputation.
However, there was a challenge of extreme class imbalance: only 3.2% of instances represented bankrupt companies (220 out of 6,819). This imbalance is common in financial datasets and required targeted techniques to prevent models from becoming biased toward predicting the majority class.



Exploratory data analysis (EDA) was conducted to understand feature behavior, detect outliers, and identify relationships with the target variable. Visualizations of class distributions confirmed the imbalance, while correlation analysis highlighted features with strong discriminatory potential.
Financial metrics such as “Debt Ratio %,” “Current Liability to Assets,” and “Borrowing Dependency” were positively correlated with bankruptcy, indicating financial stress. On the other hand, profitability features like “ROA (A),” “Net Worth/Assets,” and “Net Income to Total Assets” were negatively correlated with bankruptcy.
These findings informed both model design and interpretation, highlighting variables with strong predictive value.



Feature scaling was implemented using StandardScaler, which standardizes features to zero mean and unit variance. This step is crucial for algorithms sensitive to feature magnitudes, such as logistic regression, ensuring fair weight distribution across predictors.
Scaling was applied only after the train-test split, with the scaler fitted exclusively on the training data. This preserves the integrity of the test set and prevents data leakage.



To address the severe class imbalance, the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) was introduced to the training set. SMOTE works by generating synthetic examples of the minority class by interpolating between existing observations (Chawla et al., 2002). This ensures a balanced class distribution without simply duplicating data.
Oversampling was strictly limited to the training set, preserving the original class proportions in the test set and ensuring proper generalization.



Following pre-processing, three models were chosen: Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and XGBoost. These were selected for their interpretability and their suitability for imbalanced binary classification, offering a balance between simplicity, robustness, and interpretability.

Logistic Regression: Chosen for its linear decision boundary and interpretability. It was enhanced to handle class imbalance by setting class_weight='balanced'.
Random Forest (Breiman, 2001): Selected for its robustness and ability to handle non-linear interactions among features. Feature bagging in Random Forest also reduces overfitting and offers interpretability through feature importance scores.
XGBoost (Chen & Guestrin, 2016): Chosen for its scalability and high performance on structured data, especially when dealing with imbalanced datasets.

All models were trained using the balanced dataset (post-SMOTE) and evaluated beyond just accuracy—metrics like recall, F1-score, and ROC AUC were used to capture the ability to correctly identify bankrupt companies.



Initially, each model was trained with default hyperparameters to establish baseline performance. Then, hyperparameter tuning was performed, particularly for Random Forest, to optimize parameters such as tree depth, number of estimators, and minimum samples per split.
GridSearchCV with 5-fold cross validation was used to systematically search parameter combinations, focusing on maximizing the ROC AUC score. For instance:

n_estimators: [100, 200, 300]
max_depth: [None, 10, 20, 30]
min_samples_split: [2, 5, 10]

Logistic Regression and XGBoost were adjusted manually (e.g., max_iter=1000 for Logistic Regression to ensure convergence and eval_metric='logloss' for XGBoost). This training approach ensured all models were exposed to the same balanced data and fairly evaluated.



Multiple evaluation metrics—accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and ROC AUC—were used to fully capture performance. Considering the real-world costs of missing bankruptcies, greater emphasis was placed on recall and ROC AUC. Some experiments involved lowering the classification threshold (e.g., to 0.3 in Logistic Regression) to increase recall, acknowledging that in cost-sensitive situations, false negatives can be more damaging than false positives.
Confusion matrices and precision-recall curves were also used to analyze model misclassification patterns, especially important in highly imbalanced datasets (Saito and Rehmsmeier, 2015).

GridSearchCV with 5-fold cross validation was used to systematically search parameter combinations, focusing on maximizing the ROC AUC score. For instance:

n_estimators: [100, 200, 300]
max_depth: [None, 10, 20, 30]
min_samples_split: [2, 5, 10]

Logistic Regression and XGBoost were adjusted manually (e.g., max_iter=1000 for Logistic Regression to ensure convergence and eval_metric='logloss' for XGBoost). This training approach ensured all models were exposed to the same balanced data and fairly evaluated.

text:

title: Machine Learning Project Report
text:
2.1 Overview of Model Performance
The models were evaluated on the test set. Key metrics like accuracy and ROC AUC are summarized below:



Model
Accuracy
ROC AUC




Logistic Regression
88.34%
0.9152


Random Forest
96.04%
0.9415


XGBoost
96.33%
0.9443


Tuned Random Forest
95.97%
0.9445



While XGBoost and the Tuned Random Forest produced the highest ROC AUC scores, the Random Forest also performed exceptionally well. Logistic Regression achieved a respectable ROC AUC of 0.915 despite being a simpler baseline model.

title: Machine Learning Project Report
text:
2.2 Threshold Adjustment and Class-Specific Performance
Logistic Regression was further analyzed using a custom classification threshold of 0.3 instead of the default 0.5, significantly increasing recall at the cost of some precision:








Metric
Default Threshold (0.5)
Custom Threshold (0.3)




Recall (Class=1)
0.80
0.86


Precision (Class=1)
0.19
0.14


F1-score (Class=1)
0.31
0.23



This reflects a deliberate trade-off where false negatives are considered more costly than false positives.

title: Machine Learning Project Report
text:
2.3 Visual Evaluation
Multiple visualizations were used to gain deeper insights:

Class Imbalance and Feature Distribution: Bar charts, boxplots, and histograms highlighted the minority class and pivotal features (e.g., “Operating Profit Rate”).
Confusion Matrix Heatmaps (Figure 4): Showed relatively few false negatives for the Tuned Random Forest—critical for real-world bankruptcy detection.
ROC Curves (Figure 5): Indicated the Tuned Random Forest achieved an AUC of 0.94, confirming strong class discrimination.
Precision-Recall Curves (Figure 6): Demonstrated the trade-off between identifying bankruptcies (recall) and maintaining precision, reinforcing the model’s cost-sensitive application.
Feature Importance (Figure 7): Showed top financial stress indicators like “Debt Ratio %” and “Net Income to Total Assets” had high predictive power.

title: Machine Learning Project Report
text:
3.1 Comparative Analysis of Models
XGBoost and the Tuned Random Forest yielded the strongest metrics, with ROC AUCs above 0.94. Logistic Regression still proved useful as a simpler baseline, especially when a custom threshold was applied to improve recall for bankruptcies.
Random Forest and XGBoost both leveraged ensemble learning to handle complex, non-linear relationships. The Tuned Random Forest struck an excellent balance between strong performance and interpretability, revealed through feature importance.

title: Machine Learning Project Report
text:
3.2 Real-World Suitability
In high-stakes financial scenarios, interpretability is crucial. Although XGBoost offered marginally higher accuracy, the Random Forest provided feature importance scores, aiding transparency and stakeholder trust. For cost-sensitive contexts where missing a bankruptcy is a severe error, having insight into why a certain prediction was made is invaluable.

title: Machine Learning Project Report
text:
3.3 Limitations and Future Considerations

Only the Random Forest underwent exhaustive grid search tuning. Further tuning of Logistic Regression and XGBoost could yield performance gains.
SMOTE helped balance the training set, but the real-world class imbalance remains a challenge in deployment, potentially increasing false positives.
Future work might explore alternative sampling techniques, cost-sensitive loss functions, or advanced interpretability methods like SHAP to gain deeper insights.

title: My College Work
text: StockPath is the idea that me and my friends came up with for our college NED project. The idea came from my background in retail, as it is a stock management software solution. StockPath is a software business, built to help small business deal with the stock management issue that they face on a daily basis. We aim to create an app that pairs with a website, which will allow business owners to access valuable stock data insights at any time. We look to reduce the impacts of stock-takes too by implementing a “segmented stock-take” approach, to reduce the time consuming element of stock-takes. Click On The Image To Read The Report!
